cell.p: THE EASTERN TELEGRAPH COMPANY, LIMITED.

This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
THE EASTERN TELEGRAPH COMPANY, LIMITED.

Le réseau de cables télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie constitue le moyen de communication le plus direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique du Nord et du Sud, l'Afrique orientale, méridionale et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la Chine et le Japon. Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes doivent porter l'indication Via Eastern.

Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu' Londres au bulletin journalier publié dans ce journal. STATIONS EN EGYPTE Alexandrie, le Caire, Sues, Port-Tewak, Port-Said, Souakin. Bureau principal à Londres

div.head: Mellin's Food
div.p: For Infants
and Invalids

IS NOT FARINACEOUS. It is a fact that farinaceous foods cannot be digested by infants. In Mellin's Food the starch has been wholly changed into soluble substances capable of being rapidly converted in the body into living blood. This remarkable result is attained outside the body by imitating exactly, in the process of manufacture, the natural conditions of healthy and perfect digestion.
Rich in Flesh, Nerve, Brain and Bone Formers. MELLIN'S FOOD WORKS, PECKHAM, S.E. Representative in Egypt, Max Fischer, Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Mr. W. Ernest Walton has arrived in Egypt and is now residing at Hotel du Nil, Cairo. All retailers of postcards should without fail see the collection which he has now at his disposal for the Egyptian market. This collection is unique in the world. No time nor expense. has been prepared in the production of these postcards, which are veritable reproductions of aquarelles.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: The P. & 0.8. N. Company's Steam Yacht "VEOTIB," 6,000 tons, will leave Alexandria on Friday, the 9th and 80th of December for MAN- SEILLES, taking First Saloon Passengers only, at the usual mail rete.

div.head: The Tosh Whisky
div.p: Established 1726.
Mackintosh & C. Inverness.
Agent: Ernest Thoron, Cairo & Alexandria.
General Depot John Ross & Co. Alexandria
Retailers. E. J. Fleurent, Square Halim Pacha, Cairo.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.

On Saturday there was a moderate gale and rough sea from the N.W., with a very heavy shower of rain registering 0.1.8, the weather being continually squally and the wind unsteady from N.W. to N.E., with frequent gusts of a moderate gale. The sea was rough throughout up to 8 a.m. yesterday. Yesterday, the wind blew steadily fresh from N.W., with a rough sea, dark and heavy slow-travelling clouds throughout the day. At midnight the weather changed and the sky bo- came cloudless but slightly hazy. Barometer rising.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 8 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: BIRTH.
div.p: MACINNES - At 3, Sharia El-Manakh, Cairo, on November 13, the wife of the Rev. R. MacInnes, M.A., of a daughter.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1904.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMS.
div.p: More than once it has been a pleasure to us to acknowledge the efficiency of the services of the Cairo Tramway Company and the evident desire of the management to meet the wishes of the public in every possible manner. We have therefore no hesitation in calling the attention of the manager to the irregularity of the service between the Citadel and the Esbekieh that has for some time past been very noticeable. A correspondent who uses this service daily com- plains that of late, sometimes on two or three mornings in succession, he has had to wait ten minutes or more for a car to find, when one did arrive, that it was not only packed full but was garlanded by a picturesque array of passengers clinging to every available stanchion and handle. Such incidents are not perhaps wholly avoidable. Accidents will happen, as the old adage has it, in the best regulated families, but weare afraid that in many instances the cause of these. delays is to be attributed to the want of tact on the part of the police, who when called upon to deal with a refractory passenger, or to act upon the complaint of some one, proceed to treat the affair in a leisurely manner that is not at all justifiable. If, as occurs from time to time, the police find it necessary to make a more or less extended enquiry, or to require the attendance of a passenger, or one of the company's officials serving with the car, it should be sufficient for them to detain the persons necessary and permit the car to proceed. If it be necessary, in the interests of justice or otherwise, to detain the driver or conductor of a car, we see no reason why this should not be done and the place of the man so delayed taken by the corresponding official of the next car to arrive at the spot and making the same journey. In this way all needs would be filled and the sight now to too often seen of a string of four or more cars blocking up the traffic, while a policeman makes a close inquest into some trivial complaint, would not be so common. We cannot but think that if the company would make a suggestion of this kind to the police they would be met in every possible way and the public would profit greatly.

div.head:
THE WAR.
WINTER CAMPAIGN.
PESSIMISM AT MUKDEN.
div.p: A telegram received here from Mukden says that pessimism prevails there anent the prospects of a winter campaign. It is believed that the transport supply question will be the most difficult.
(Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN WAR LOAN.
div.p: The Echo de Paris learns from St. Peters- burg that a Russian loan of £53,000,000 has been arranged with German and Dutch banks. £45,000,000 will be issued in Germany and the rest at Amsterdam. The greater part of the money is to remain in Germany, and will be used as a guarantee in connection with. orders for numerous warships. (Reuter.)

div.head: JAPAN'S FOREIGN LOAN. FINANCE MINISTER NOT SATISFIED.

div.p: The prospectus of the Japanese loan, men- tioned on the 8th inst., has been issued. The loan is repayable in 1911, and secured on the Customs. (Reuter.)

The Minister for Finance states that the Government is not satisfied with the terms of the foreign loan, but the delay in the capture of Port Arthur and the departure of the Baltic Fleet compelled the acceptance of terms less favourable than the first loan. (Reuter.)

div.head: TRANS-SIBERIAN RAILWAY. DOUBLING OF TRACK.
div.p: The Tsar has approved of the scheme for doubling the track of the Trans-Siberian Railway.
(Reuter.)
The Chamber has approved of M. Delcassé's declaration anent the Anglo-French Agreementby 438 votes to 94.
(Reuter.)
The Chamber of Deputies has passed theAnglo-French Convention.
(Havas.)
The Chamber has ratified the Franco-Sin mese Convention, and also the Anglo-French Convention concerning Newfoundland and West and Central Africa, by 443 votes to 105. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE KOWEY DIFFICULTY. LORD LANSDOWNE'S REPLY.
div.p: Lord Lansdowne told the Porte that the Agent is only at Koweyt temporarily in order to settle certain affairs. His lordship, however, cannot deal with the case so long as the Aden" question is not settled. (Reuter.)

div.head:
AMERICAN NAVY
BIG INCREASE IN PERSONNEL.
div.p: The Government is increasing the personnel of the Navy to 64,445 men, which is more than double the number at present. The increase is in connection with the new building programme
(Reuter.)

div.head: HORSHAM ELECTION.
div.p: Lord Tumour, Conservative and Chamber lainite, has been elected by 4,388 votes against Mr. Erskine, Liberal, 8,604.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
QUESTION OF NEUTRALITY.
div.p: The Temps states that the Japanese Minister called upon M. Delcassé yesterday with reference to certain points relating to tho observance of neutrality by France. There are grounds for believing that divergences of opinion have arisen. The same, however, must not be over-rated as they will soon be removed, since France has hitherto reconciled her duties as an ally of Russia with those of a neutral Power. Japan, on the other hand, appreciates the uprightness of French intentions in the delicate situation. Explanations are proceeding amicably.
The above doubtless refers to coaling and other naval facilities which have been given to the Russians by French colonies. (Reuter.)

div.head: DIVERGENCES OF OPINION.
div.p: It is stated that Japan has called the atten- tion of the governments to the maintenance of a striet neutrality with regard to the passage of the Russian Baltic Squadron. (Havas.)
Four Russian battleships, 5 cruisers and 7
transports have arrived here.
(Reuter.)
(Havas.)
The Russian Fleet has arrived.

div.head: FRENCH SENATE
div.p: M. Wallon, Senator, is dead
M. Destournelles has been elected Senator
Havas.

div.head: SYVETON-DUGAIL DUEL
div.p: The duel between M. Syveton and Captain Duguail has taken place. Two shots were exchanged without result.
Havas.

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: Mr. Valentine Prinsep, the artist, and Mr. George Lennox Watson, the yacht designer, are dead.
Reuter.

div.head: TRANSPORT OF CATTLE
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has issued instructions to all Governors and Moudirs on the subject of the transport of cattle.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: M. Silvain, the celebrated French tragedian, opens a short season at this theatre this evening with Victor Hugo's Le Roi s'amuse.

div.head: A COMPETITOR TO EGYPT.
div.p: It is announced that the people of Sindh are this year export ing three hundred thousand bales of improved cotton equal to Egyptian.

div.head: FRENCH SCHOOL OF LAW.
div.p: The beginning of the course for the three years licentiate at the French School of Law at Cairo is fixed for Thursday next, 17th inst., at 3.30 p.m.

div.head: MEDICAL LICENSES.
div.p: Drs. J. S. Bordach and Emin Malouf have been authorised by the Ministry of the Interior to practise in Egypt. M. Franz Moldehuke has been authorised to practise as a pharmacist.

div.head: BRITISH SOLDIER DROWNED.
div.p: On Saturday afternoon the corpse of Private Sinclair, of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, was found in the Nile at Ghizeh. The funeral took place yesterday afternoon.

div.head: NEWSPAPER LIBEL CASE
div.p: Mr. Gammal, a wealthy Alexandrian, has brought an action for libel against the proprietor and editor of the Tamiel, a local Arabic newspaper. £1000 damages are claimed.

div.head: THE ANNIVERSARY
div.p: of the death of Ismail Pasha was commemorated yesterday evening at the Daira of Kasr el-Aly by a religious cere- mony. Some verses of the Koran were read and'alms were given to the poor at the ceme- tery of the Khedivial family.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: On the 10th inst. 11 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. were British and 1 was Prench. and passenger dues for the day amounted to 314,821.49 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st inst. to that date on 120 vessels amounted to 3,174,893.54 frs.

div.head: MR. JOHN B. CAPPARI
div.p: wishes to inform his clients that, owing to the expiration of the lease of his old premises in the Grand Square his offices and stores have been removed to 8, Rue de l'Eglise Debbane and 6, Boulevard de Ramleh. As the fittings of the offices, shop, and stores are not yet completed, some of the back stores will be used temporarily, with entrance from 8, Rue de l'Eglise Debbane.

div.head: THE HORSHAM ELECTION
div.p: results, asgiven in this morning's telegrams, are cold comfort for the Ante-Chamberlainites. The late member, Mr. Heywood Johnstone, was so well known and so popular in the constituency, which he had represented since 1893, that it was diffi cult for a new candidate to fill his place in the favours of that division of the county, but Lord Turnour has romped in with nearly 800 votes to the good.

div.head: A NEW HOSPITAL
div.p: will shortly very probably be erected in Old Cairo by the Church Missionary Society. It will be an extension of the Society's present hospital and will be constructed specially for the use of women and children. It is to be erected in memory of the wife of Dr. Maynard Pain, of the C.M.S. in Old Cairo. That lady, it will be remembered, died in Cairo a year ago. It is estimated that nearly £2,400 will be required and of this sum nearly £1,900 has already been subscribed.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive held an "Iftar" on Saturday evening at Abdeen Palace, which was attended by a large number of retired high officials.

His Highness received Commodore Coun douriotis, the Admiral of the Greek Fleet, and his commanding officers this morning at Abdeen Palace. They were presented to the Khedive by M. Gennadis, Hellenic Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Cairo.

div.head: MENA HOUSE COACH UPSET
div.p: An accident that might have been very serious happened to the Mena House coach yesterday morning, about half-a-mile from the bridge. One of the horses-a magnificent team recently imported from Hungary-became restive and swerved to the left close to the trees, against one of which the coach collided.. Owing to the impact the entire coach turned turtle and the four passengers, driver, and groom were thrown to the ground. The driver pluckily stuck to his reins and did his utmost to avert disaster, and owing to his own cool- ness was thrown rather heavily in front of the coach. He was unconscious for a few minutes but was at once rescued from the horse by the passengers, who had by this time alighted. The groom crushed his foot and was taken to the German Hospital and is little the worse beyond a fow contusions.

A subscription of 10 shillings was collected among the passengers and presented to the driver by Mr. Norman Hamilton, who was on the box-seat at the time of the accident, and who addressed a few complimentary remarks to the driver, a brave Italian, who deserved the utmost credit for his conduct and to whom not the slightest blame attached.

div.head: HELOUAN
div.p: The Grand Hotel Helouan is daily receiving new arrivals. We notice among the visitors at this hotel Mr. A. Byddulph Myddelton, Mr. and Mrs. Pettigrew, from London, Mr. Schwerin, M. A. Rossano, Mr. S. A. Fisher and Dr. Campbell Ward, from Harrogate, Mr. Sidney Halifax, Mr. Wright Henderson, M. F. Suares, from Cairo, Mr. Ed. Downham, from Poole, Mr. J. Bibby, from Birkenhead, Mr. Bretschneider, Mrs. and the Misses Gollock, from London.

Many applications for rooms have been received lately. Among the visitors shortly expected are: Col. and Mrs. Spearman, Mrs. Birley, Mr. Fildes, Mr. and Mrs. Jebb Scott, Capt. and Mrs. W. Leetham, Mr. and Mrs. Th. Jimmins and party, Miss James and party. The golf professional, who has been specially engaged by the manager of the Grand Hotel, is expected in a few days, and the links is now open for the use of visitors staying either at the Grand Hotel or at the Hotel des Bains.

The Bath Establishment of Helouan, under the management of the George Nungovich Hotels Company, has been entirely renewed during the last summer. Three more of the famous so-called Helouan baths (bath with massage under water) have been added during the summer. From now and during the whole season eight European experienced masseurs and masseuses from Aix-les-Bains and Harrogate, will be in attendance. A new Vichy bath will also be installed at the Bath Establishment, which may be visited at any time of the day.

div.head: REDUCTION OF GARRISON.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Dear Sir, Some time ago I sent you a very characteristic comment of the Duke of Wel- lington on the reductions in the Indian army which precipitated the Sikh war. I trust you will find space in your columns for a selection from the second volume of Lord Dalhousie's Life, which explains readily why the great event of 1857 was so very nearly successful. In 1854 Lord Dalhousie wrote to Sir Charles Wood:-

"I cannot believe that the Queen's Government would diminish the compara- tively small European force in India without any reference to the Government of the country. I wish to say to you emphatically that two European regiments cannot be safely withdrawn, especially now. Our Raj is safe from risk, but only while we are strong. We positively must not be weaken- ed. I adjure you not to allow us to be weakened in European infantry."

In a subsequent minute he recorded:-"The Government of India has no element of national strength on which it can fall back in a country where the entire English community is but a handful of scattered strangers.
History has an unfortunate habit of repeating itself, and I put this quotation before those of my countrymen in whose eyes two and two make four and not two two's.
Yours truly,

div.head: SAILOR DROWNED
div.p: At eleven o'clock on Saturday morning, while the train containing 750 sailors and petty officers from all the ships of the Greek squadron was on the bridge of the Mahmou- dich Canal, going to the Antoniades Garden, one of the sailors of the Iydrw, by name Spindor Milionis, got out of the train and fell through one of the spaces in the bridege, near Hadra station, and after being severely stun- ned, fell into the canal, where he was ultimately drowned. The body of the unfortunate ma was not found until 6 o'clock in the evening and was then taken to the Greek Hospital for identification, etc. The body remained there all night.

div.head: THE FUNERAL
div.p: At 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a small detachment from the ship Hydra, accompanied by the band of the vessel, escorted the body of the deceased sailor, which was placed on a gun carriage, to the Greek cemetery, followed by a vast concourse of people. The burial services was read by the local Bishop, at the chapel of the Greek-Orthodox cemetery. The body was then deposited in the grave and three volleys were fired by the escort. There were three big wreaths, one from the crew of the Hydra, one from the Hellenic community, and one from Mr. Anthony Benachi. The chief mourner was represented by Mr. Sootides, the Consul-General. Besides all the officers of the ship we remarked Mr. Michel Sinadino, the personnel of the Greek Consulate, the Greek Judge, Mr. G. Zervudachi, Dr. Valasopoulo, Mr. M. S. Salvago, Mr. N. Sinadino. Mr. Ant. and Alex. Benachi, Mr. Paraskevas, Mr. E. Minotto, the personnel of the Greek Hospital, and many others. The crowd at the cemetery and along the roads outside may be estimated at about 10,000 people. After the conclusion of the ceremony, the escort marched back to the ship, headed by the band playing a march, and accompanied by a large crowd of people.

div.head: SATURDAY'S PICNIC
div.p: In spite of the death of the sailor Milionis, which threatened to postpone the proceedings, the pienie given in honour of the petty officers and sailors of the fleet came off at 12 o'clock on Saturday. Over 750 men sat down to lunch, which was provided by Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., of Alexandria, at the Anto nindes Garden, on the Mahmoudieh Canal. At another table all the leading members of the Hellenic community lunched, amidst the strains of the band of the Greek Philharmonic Society. In the afternoon all the ladies of the Hellenic colony here appeared, and the men danced the Greek national danoes. The pro- ceedings terminated at 4 o'clock with the singing of the Greek National Anthem.

At 7.30 on Saturday evening H.E. Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, gave a dinner in honour of the Commodore of the Grook Fleet at the Khedivial Club of Alex andria. His Excellency, who was accompanied by his private secretary, had on his right M. Sootides, the Hellenic Consul-General at Alex- andria, on his left Commodore Coundouriotis, and opposite M. Gennadis, the Greek Diplom atic Agent in Cairo, on whose right was Captain Ghinis, of the flag-ship Paara, and on his left Captain Damianos, of the Hydra.

Among the others invited were Mr. E. Bena- chi, the president of the Hellenic community, Mr. M. Sinadino, Colonel Hopkinson Bey, the Groek judges, Messrs. Pangalo, Dimaras, Anto- niadis, and Papadopoulo, Mr. M. Salvago, Mr. Amb. Ralli, Mr. N. Tamvaco, Mr. G. Zervuda- chi, and Mr. Ch. Simopoulo.

div.head: DEPARTURE FOR CAIRO
div.p: On Sunday at midday the Greek Commodore D. Coundouriotis, with his staff, five officers from each ship, the head officer of the Commissariat department, the chief doctor, the head engineer, and the chaplain left for Cairo, accompanied by M. Gennadis, the Greek Diplomatic Agent at Cairo, by whom they were presented to his Highness the Khedive. By the same train Mr. E. Bonachi, president of the Greek community, also left. They are patting up at the Continental Hotel, where rooms had been reserved for them. We understand that the programme to be followed in Cairo is the following:

Monday. Presentation to H.H. the Khedive. Then a Te Deum at the Greek-Orthodox Church St. Nicola, and at night a dinner at the Continental Hotel, given in honour of the officers by the Greek colony at Cairo. Tuesday. Picnic to the Barrage.
Wednesday. Excursion to the Pyramids, where tea will be given, and a "Punch" at the Greek Club given to the officers by the Hellenic colony of Cairo.

div.head: New York dogs
div.p: are now fitted out with on armoured coat staddol with sharp steel spikes, to enable them to play "teuch las" on the public highway without that risk of getting squashed by a motor car which so annoys the high-spirited dog. If the armoured dog is run into by a car. his spikes puncture the tyre and the rush of released air blows him out of danger.

div.head: THE CATTLE PLAGUE
NEW REGULATIONS
div.p: The following arrêté has been issued by the Ministry of the Interior-
Art. 1. Without the previous authorisation of the authorities designed by the Sanitary Administration and conformity with the provisions of the said authorisation,
(a) The transport of cattle or buffaloes from one village to another, and,
(6) The trade in and transport of dried hides and bones of cattle are forbidden. Art. 2. It is strictly prohibited
(a.) To engage in the trade in or transport of raw hides;
(6) To slaughter any cattle or buffaloes outside the public abattoirs in localities declared infected by cattle plague;
(e) To transport from one village to another the flesh of cattle unless they have been slaughtered in such abattoirs.

3. The decres of June 14, 1904, is hereby abrogated and replaced by the present decroo 4. The present decree shall come into force at once and remain in force for 6 months unless previously abrogated.

div.head: THE LATE TIGRANE PASHA
div.p: The body of Tigrane Pasha arrives at Alex- andria this afternoon by the North German Lloyd 8.8 Belleig. The Sub-Governor of Alexandria and a detachment of police will proceed to the quays to receive the body, which is to be despatched this afternoon to Cairo by a special train direct from the quay.

div.head: THE NEW STEAMSHIP LINE
div.p: The arrival of the S.S. Schleswig at Alexandria this afternoon inaugurates the new Mediterranean service of the North German Lloyd. The Schleseig left Marseilles on Wednesday and Naples at noon on Friday. She had 235 passengers on board, of whom 185 were first and 59 second class. Among the passengers were Prince Aslan d'Abro Pagradite, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bayerlé, Mme. Bastros, Prince and Princess Hussein, Izzet Pashs and Princess Faika It, Baron and Baronne Messe, Tuemi Bey, Mr. Michael Sursock, Comte and Comtesse de Serioane, Mme. C. Salvago, Boghos Pasha Nubar, and Mrs. G. B. Alderson.

div.head: NEW ARCHAELOGICAL SOCIETY
div.p: A now society has been successfully started in Paris under most distinguished suspices, in imitation of the Egypt, Palestine, and Cretan Exploration, Punds. It is entitled "La Société Françaiso de Fouilles Archéolo giques. The first grant of funds will almost certainly be apportioned to M. Gayet to assist him in further excavations at Antinos. As evidence of the "entente cordiale," the committee are desirous of having British members, and our correspondent Mr. Offord is the first such elected. The prosident is M. Babelon of the "Cabinet des Medailles." The annual subscription, which entitles members to the publications, is 20 francs.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
div.p: This theatre was again crowded on Saturday evening, when Verdi's Il Trovatore was produced, and it was evident from the rounds of applause bestowed on the artistes throughgat the evening that the performance fully reached their expectations, and was indeed an unqualified success. Signor Fabbri's Aroma is an interpretation of that difficult we the like of which, both from a musical and histrionic point of view, it has seldom been our pleasure to hear. As Leonora Signors, Popovici moored another distinct success. She sang and acted with that graco and skill which always characterised her performances, and with Signs Fabbri, shared in the anthesisatio plandits so lavishly bestowed and so richly deserved. Both these ladies were presented with) handsome bouquets. Signor Venerandi was a very acceptable Manrico and met with hearty applause. The famous aria at the end of the third act he was compelled to repeat no loss than thrice. The whole of the artistes were recalled continually

A word of praise is again due to the chorus. for the excellent manner in which their work is performed, the hidden chorusos being particularly pleasing. It is hardly necessary to say that the orchestra, under the able baton of Sig. Falooni, was, as it always is, perfection..

The performance was under the distinguished patronage and presence of H.B. the Governor of Alexandria, who occupied the Khe dive's box, accompanied by the Commodore and officers of the Greek Squadron. A large number of Greek naval officers and many local notables were also present in other parts of the house.
This evening there will be no performance. To-morrow Andrea Chenier will be given, with Signa. Popovici in the caste.
Yesterday's Italian mailboat brought the celebrated singer Signa. Monti-Baldini and the tenor Alfredo Torniani, who will shortly make their appearance in Carmen and Mignon.

div.head: YACHTING
div.p: The British turbine yacht Emerald, which is bound for a cruise to the China Seas, left Alexandria harbour yesterday evening.
The French yacht Fiorentina II. also sailed yesterday evening bound in the same direction as the Emerald.

div.head: COQUELIN AINE AT CAIRO
div.p: "TARTUFE"

We had Tartufe, followed by Les Precieuses Ridicules, on Thursday night, and the Opita House was, quite naturally, full and the audience as enthusiastic as it could be Co quelin's Tartuffe was of course the performance that dwarfed everything else. His-cons mand and control of facial expression were equally amazing. He never underlined, and to the British theatre-goer, who is accustomed to over-casting, that fact alone was almost-as astonishing as his historie sense. Tartufo is no modern imposter as loquacious as be is underbrod, all things-to all men and more shamelessly fluent than his prospectus. He is the typical imposter of a dignified epoch-when- the lowest villains had a grand air and when honest people were not compelled to career through life, at high pressure under pain-of being outstripped by their friends, and.cat sequently had time to look around thon and, among other interesting subjects, to study character. We do not say they studied it consciously or as a science, but having produe. ed a very distinct and general type of educated. man, who differed as greatly from the man of the fifteenth century as he differs from the man of the nineteenth, they insisted on,the necessity incumbent on all decent persons to be tamped with part at least of the pattern of a peial trademark. Nowadays we would not He duped by Tartafe, who would be universally cut as a sanctimonious bore or as aoonistent eccentric. Yet, we seem to remember cases in country towns where ditions who were distinguished as "worthy or Christian' men and had even become churchwardens, ended their days in gaol or were last heard of in South American republics.
Of the other actors, Mlle Suzanne Devoyod made a very charming Elvire, but Mlle Bou chetal was not very distinct and M. Chabert (Damis) overacted.

After the performance of Tartufe camo Les Précieuses Ridicules and a great improvement in the other members of the company, who had aot been able to save the Alexandrines of Tartufe from monotony only relieved by Coquelin's splendid enunciation and delivery of the long lines. Mllo Devoyod was again good a Magdalen, but rather failed to bring out the humour of her part, and Mlle Bouchatal as Cathos greatly improved on her Doringre. M. Rosenberg, who had made Orgon too much, in our opinion, of a buffoon in Tartufe, repeated the Orgonic gestures as Gorgibus. Coquetin's rendering of Mascarille's song deserved even more than the applause it received.

div.head: "L'ABBE CONSTANTIN"
div.p: On Friday night L'Abbé Constantin made a welcome reappearance in Cairo, and was well received by an appreciative house. The piece is merely a parlour play, and albeit light and trifling, rivets the attention of the spectator by its amusing situations and dialogue. M. Coquelin again showed himself a master of the quiet method of acting, as opposed to the florid style that involves so much violent gesticulation and rushing about the stage; trusting to his inimitable variety of expression, be assumed now a look of bland innocence, now a twinkle of arch cynicism, followed by a most suave and affable smile to his friends and guests, while his unique powers of articulation made even his whispers audible all over- the house. We liked him beat in the third act, though in the first his dinner and siesta were most amusingly rendered. It is a pity that the mise-en-some and the characters call for so little comment, with the exception perhaps of Mmo. Suzanne Devoyod and some spirited acting by M. Rosenberg, which met with the appreciation it deserved.

div.head: "CYRANO DE BERGERAC"
div.p: Le cœur a ses raisons, which opened Saturday night's performance, is an amusing little curtain-raiser, slight, witty, and well-perform- ed, but we would have given anything to hear another act of Cyrano de Bergerac. We had the 3rd and 5th acta with Coquelin at his best. The staging of the balcony scene was hopelessly bad, but the fact that the night, on which all depends, was thoroughly illuminated, had no difference whatever to the quality of his performance. Many first-rate actors would have faltered before the unreality of the mise-en- scène, but Coquelin carried through magnificently what is probably his finest performance. If you doubt it fead Cyrano and try to imagine the possibility of such a man in real life. Yet Coquelin makes him not only possible but eminently probable and convincing.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal, which left Marseilles on Thursday, passed through the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here to-morrow morning.
The Ellerman S.S. Athenian arrived here on Friday afternoon from Liverpool, and Gibraltar with mails and general cargo.

div.head: TELEGRAPH ADMINSTRATION
div.p: Tantah, Sunday. I am glad to place on record that, after my repeated complaints, the Telegraph Administration has at last taken steps to improve the service here. A supplementary line is now working with Alexandria, and the result is that telegrams are transmitted quickly (6 minutes for ordinary telegrams in some cases). I met congratulate the Telegraph Department on having met the claims of the public.

div.head: GREEK VICE CONSUL
div.p: Mr. Nicolas Golemas, Greek Vice-Consul in Tantab, has been replaced by an official from the Alexandria Consulate. There are rumours that he will not return here.

div.head: THE TANZIM
div.p: The Tanzim Department here, as elsewhere in Egypt, seems to have been created against- the interests of the town. Now that the electric light has been installed, all the old lampe, etc.; have had to be put away, and as the Tanzitn people had no room in the stores they have simply barricaded the side street near the stores at both ends and now use this as stones is

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The King of Italy has bestowed on the Governor of Alexandria the 3rd class (co- mander) of the Order of the Italian Crown

The death is announced of the Archimandrite Germanos, who for some years past had represented the Patriarch of Alexandria at the Ecumenical Patriarchate The Arobimaadrite died suddenly on Friday week as the residence of Mgr. Mihall, Metropolitan of Sardes and- Director of the National School at Phanany with whom he had been staying, sinos the previous Wednesday.

The funeral of Miss Mary Barsook the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Bumeok will take place tomorrow. The outage will leave the residence of the deceased's parents at 72, Rosetta avenue, at 3.30 p.m.
Dr. Allingham, whose reputation as a surgical operator was world-wide, while on his way hat week to Egypt, where he intended to make long stay for the benefit of his health, died at Marseilles.
Professor Schweinfurth leaves Berlin to-day for Egypt.
Mr. and Mrs. A. J. Michaelides have left for Heloam, to spend the winter season

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUICIARE
div.p: TRIBUNAL CIVIL MIXTE D'ALEXANDRIE
L'Affaire Faik Pacha

Faik Pacha avait été cité par devant le Tribunal Mixte de Justice Sommaire d'A- lexandrie par un certain Akimovitch aux fins de s'entendre condamner à lui payer la somme de 100 L.T. à titre d'indemnité pour le service qu'il lui a rendu en loi ra- menant sa femme de Constantinople à Alexandrie.
Le Tribunal saisi avait condamné Feik Pacha au paiement de la somme de 25 Liv Les deux parties firent appel de ce juge- ment. Voici le texte de la sentence rendue. par le tribunal civil mixte :

"Statuant publiquement et contradic toirement en matière civile et en degrét d'appel, déclare Faik Pacha recevable et fondé en son app.1 et rejetant l'appel inci- dent d'Akimovitch, réformant le jugement attaqué, déboute Akimovitch de sa demande en paiement de 100 L.T.; l'aatorise toute- fois à retirer du Poste de Police de Ramleh les 7 livres sterling qui y ont été déposées par Faik Pacha pour lui être remises et au cas où cette somme ne se trouverait plos aux mains de la police, ordonne à Faik Pacha de la payer à Akimovitch.
Condamne ce dernier à tous les dépens de 1re instance et d'appel, honoraires d l'avocat de Faik Pacha taxés à P.T. 800 pour les 2 instances."

Voici un court aperçu des motifs invo- qués par le juge: Aucane convention n'est établie au fond; le prétendu mandat sui- vant lequel la dame Faik Pacha aurait agi pour compte et au nom de son mari n'est pas une base suffisante; la reconnaissance par la pacha d'une dette de 7 livres n'im- plique pas un aveu mais le désir d'en finir avec cette affaire; les dettes de la femme ne tombent point d'après le droit musulman à la charge du mari; il est d'ailleurs si difficile de démêler la vérité dans ce procès qu'une action contre la dame elle-même serait peut-être sans résultat; aucune explication concluante des dépenses qu'il a faites n'est fournie par Akimovitch; celui-ci, même en se réclamant d'un quasi-contrat de gestion d'affaires, qualificatif d'ailleurs étrange en l'espèce, n'aurait droit à la restitution des dépenses que jusqu'à concurrence du profit obtenu.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: La corbeille des valeurs a présenté la semsine passée une grande animation, non pas sur les grosses valeurs qui sont resté s plutôt délaissés, mais sur les petites, par- ticulièrement la Delta Land, la Salt & Sod et les Markets.

Les affaires en Delta Land ont été énormes. C'est de 10000 à 15000 qu'il faut évaluer le nombre de titres échangés dans le courant de la semaine. Le cours a été poussé jusqu'à 4 1/16 ici et 4 3/16 au Caire. C'est d'ailleurs de cette dernière ville que nous est venu le principal mouvement, basé, dit-on, sur la rameur d'une nouvell émission. Le prix d'aujourd'hui est de 8 27/32 acheteurs.

La Salt & Soda avait débuté ferme à 31 et atteint 84; elle avait ensuite faibli en clôture à 33/6 pour reprendre aujourd'hui à 84/3 obetura. La demande croissante de la spéculation fait prévoir des prix encore plus élevés.

Bien que les recettes des Markets soit peu satisfaisantes, comparées à celles de la semaine correspondante de 1908, cette valear reste cependant en grande faveur auprès du public. A 24 au début de la semaine, elle clôturait samedi à 26/6.

Il y a peu de choses à dire sur les grosses6 valeurs. La Banque Nationale débute ferme à 22 7/8 et atteint 23 5/8 dans le courant de la semaine, pour clôturer à 23 3/8 par suite des réalisations. La Daïra a été plus demandée que la semaine précédente. La Delta Light reste sans changement. L'A- gricole, après avoir débuté ferme, avait faibli vers le milieu de la semaine. Elle reprend aujourd'ubi à 10 15/16. La Béhéra flotte entre 58 1/2 et 54.

En somme notre marché est en bonne tendance. L'argent y est encore assez abondant et la crise monétaire ne semble pas trop prochaine. Les marchés euro- péens continuent à rechercher nos va- leurs et le taux de l'escompte se maintient nasex bas, à 27/8.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS
div.p: NOTICE.

The Board of Administration has the honour to inform the public that, commencing on Wednesday 16th and Thursday 17th November, the "Train de Laxe," composed of sleeping and dining-cars only, wil run between Cairo, Laxor and back as follows:- From Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday, leaving Cairo station at 6 80 p m., on and a ter 16th November.

The sleeping-car and dining-car on the night Expres, leaving Cairo at 8p m.. and Laxor at 5.80 p.m., will be suppressed from the above date. Passengers are requested to give early notice of the berths they require to the Sleeping Car Company, Catro Biation.
Cairo, 8th November, 1904.

div.head: GUNNY BAG MARKET
div.p: The market opened firm after the holidays, a fair amount of business being put through in both plain and twilled goods, and the prospects are for a continuation of present rates for some time.

There were orders from the U.K. and Continent, which markets have practically absorbed all the export business that has been passing, the Australian Colonies, Burmah, and the Far East putting forward but few enquiries.

Speculators on the other hand have been taking forward lines of E bags at Rs.19, Heavy Cs at Rs.25, and various descriptions of twilled goods at the equivalent of about Rs.25 for 44" 2 lb. B Twills, the advance in the price of loose jute and the reports from the interior of a shrinkage in the available supplies of the raw material making mills disinclined to go on selling, and this has in itself helped to stiffen the market to some extent.

HESSIANS have hardened in value, more in sympathy with the general firmness of the gunny market, than by orders from consuming centres, and a fair quantity of both nine and eleven porter cloth has been taken for Jan/ June; the closing prices being Rs.7-9 and Rs.9-10 respectively.

For this year the heavier texture is still in demand for the Argentine and Rs.10-8 is being paid for this month's shipment, the asking price for early November being Rs. 10-4 and December Rs. 10; 40 8 oz. cloth quotes Rs. 7-12 Novr. and Rs. 7-11 December, there being little available for these months.

div.head: BOURSE KHEDIVIALE
div.p: Remarques sur le marché da disponible es
Contrats.
Coton:
Samedi, le 12 novembre 1904.

Disponible.-L'état du disponible pendant presque toute la semaine a permis aux exportateurs de faire des achats asses suivis et de défsire bon nombre de leurs couvertures en contrats, mais, comme demandes nouvelles de la part de la filatare, il n'y en a ea que fort pen. Le marché a été soutenu par suite de la tenue des contrats; les prix ont hauseó de 1/8 à 8/8 suivant la qualité.
Franco gare: La situation est toujours la même, ce qui rend toute affaire impossible.

Contrats. Récolte acta lle. Le commerce a figuré du côté vendeurs, mais la spéculation n'en a pas été impressionnée et elle n'a cessé d'influencer le marché. Le sentiment est toujours pour la hausse; la preuve en est que les résotions qui se prodai- sent ne sont que passagères et que les nouvelles de l'Etranger ne sont prises en considération que quand elles sont favorables aux idées des acheteurs.

Nouvelles récolte. Ne donne lien qu'à des affaires in-ignifiantes; en réalité, la valeur du novembre 1905 ne se maintient qu'à cause de la récolte notuelle. Il est à noter toutefois que les vendears sérieux manquent sur le marché.
Dans la matinée; Prix plus haut pour nov., talaris 15 9/16 à 1983: plus bas pour nov. 15 7/16-- Graines de coton:

Disponible.-Les fluctuations des cours ont été de peu d'importance; da reste, la demande était lente et avec les arrivages réguliers que nous avons eus, il n'y avait pas lieu à des changements marqués.
La demande de l'exportation reste insignifiante. Franco gare: Rien.

Contrats.-Récolte actuelle. Les contrats sont négligés. La tenue est toutefois assez bonne, les cours actuels n'étant pas encourageants pour les vendeurs. Les reports augmentent, ce qui devrait donne à réfléchir.

div.head: UNDER THE MOSQUITO NET
div.p: It is my aim in writing these papers to deal with the subjects on which they treat in a manner that will make them acceptable on general grounds. Religion, politics, and kindred fi subjects are capable of being approached from a th standpoint that to a great extent avoids con- m troversy and with which only the narrow- en minded can find fault. The same remark b applies to matters of local interest involving at questions of principle, and it is on one or two of these that I propose to write this week.

Place aux dames. A kind-hearted lady M writes to me calling my attention to the need- less cruelties inflicted on animals and birds. and asking me to undertake a crusade on be- half of the sufferers. I am afraid that my ta correspondent greatly overrates my capacities h in this direction, though I need hardly say t that my sympathies are fully enlisted, and t have been for a long time, in the work of preventing cruelty to the animal world. Two w questions are asked in the letter and they are h very pertinent ones.
Cannot the Arabs be induced to carry "wretched birds of all kinds otherwise than "by swinging them about head downwards, "their legs tied by fine cord!
"Must dogs be poisoned in such a manner "that they writhe in agonising convulsions for "more than half an hour at a time!"

The sight of birds being carried through the streets head downwards is so common a one that I fear it passes almost unnoticed. Whe ther the practice is a worse one than that of packing them for market in crates so closely that the poor creatures cannot possibly move, -which from frequent observation in Leaden- hall market I know to be the custom in Eng- land, I will not stop to enquire. Two wrongs never did and never will make a right, and we are at present dealing with Egyptian methods, which are bad enough in all conscience. Nor is the cruelty confined to the practice of carry- ing the birds. They are often killed in the most brutal manner, being stabbed and thrown on the pavement to bleed to death. And this not by Arabs alone but also by young Euro- pean lads, who appear equally callous, the sight being frequently witnessed by children who are quick to learn lessons in cruelty. And what of the example set by 'society' parents in the 'sport' (!) of pigeon shooting at the Rond Point Velodrome 1 Readers of the Gazette, do you ever think about such things, or do you enter your sweepstakes in the full consciousness that you may only 'wing' your bird and cause it painfully flutter out the life that you did not give and have no right to take away Here lies one great stumbling-block in the way of teaching the Arab to be merciful. Precept and practice should go together.

With regard to the dog poisoning, I am sure that such wretched bungling as that described needs only to be represented to the authorities who order the destruction of the animals, to be at once prohibited. I believe that in Alexandria the necessary orders are given by Captain Lynn, than whom a kinder- hearted man cannot easily be found. I feel sure that if more, supervision of this duty is required the captain will give it, in spite of his numerous and pressing duties. My correspondent cannot do better than address a letter to this officer giving him a few of the facts she has mentioned to me. She says, "I am tired of acting the part of the Levite and the Pharisee." I would say that far from so doing she is in reality already helping to alleviate the suffer- ings of the poor creatures for whom she pleads, for it is beginning to be recognised that thoughts are things, and that we can send out into the unseen wishes, sympathies, and aspira- tions that bear fruit either for good or evil. Even in this stage of life man has capacities little dreamed of by most people, and which a comparatively short study of psychic matters clearly reveals. More of this anon, if the Editor does not think I am travelling too far afield.

One other matter of local interest I should like to touch upon, viz., the exclusion of the Press from the deliberations of the Municipality. In a leading article on the subject in Wed- nesday's Gazette the Editor lays it down as an axiom that all prima facie considerations based analogically on the principles in force in other civilised countries are totally inappli cable to Egypt. Probably he is right. If one thing more than another has struck me since I have been in this country it is the way in which the obsolete and the modern go hand in hand. You may see a steam road roller at work in one street and in another the old-fashioned solid roller to which oxenare yoked, slowly levelling the road. Suburban roads, beautifully metalled, drained, and swept, are skirted by footpaths both dirty and dan- th gerous. The motor Fire-king comes flashing along at I am afraid to say how many miles an hour, and it is manned by about as incom- of petent a set of men as the Municipality can ve find for their chief. And then contrasts meet the eye at every step one takes. Up-to-date in fa many respects, and mostly where private for enterprise is concerned, Alexandria is sadly behind the times in others-in her represent G ative institutions lamentably so. Where is the sense in granting the citizens the right of th electing representatives if the men elected are f to be beyond the control of the electors? I wish Mr. G. B. Alderson would resign his member- ship and offer himself for re-election, and thus give the electors the chance of saying if they wish the meetings of their representatives to take place in camera. If they say "no" his hands will be greatly strengthened by taking it this course; on the other hand, if they refuse to support him in his efforts to let daylight re into the council-room I would say he will be well out of an impasse in which he can only do be his duty to the public by placing himself in an invidious position that as a business man no one has a right to expect him to fill.

Are these matters quite without the province to of the British advisers ? It appears to me that as far as showy policy in Egypt is concerned, Nile dams, etc., all that can be done is done; but what of the many social questions that go to make up the life of a nation ? Echo answers, What How far have Lord Milner's anticipations of twelve years ago been realized, and what prospect is there for the future?
I am afraid I have already exhausted the patience of my readers. Next week I will give local matters a rest.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM
div.p: Professor Forbes, whose former letter to the Times on the subject of the advantages of the Kaibar, as compared with the Assouan Dam, was reproduced recently in our columns, writes sas follows to the Times:-

In the note I sent you about the possibility nt of making a Nile dam with every natural facility at Kaibar, sufficient to supply all the water asked for by irrigation engineers, I did not mention the chief advantage. If this were done the Assouan dam might be used as an o auxiliary only, to let off water when required. At other times its value would be as a power dam for transmitting electric power, chiefly for the pumping and lighting and railways. The chief demand for power being her pumps, which re need not be working all day and night at full of power, the irregular demands, such as lighting, ad, could be supplied at a very low cost, permitting transmission to unusually long distances, a feature which is further favoured by the facility of maintaining the insulation on a line mostly at traversing the desert.

div.head: "BAKSHISH."
div.p: A TIMELY WARNING.
The following important notice has been issued by the authorities:-

The attention of the Egyptian authorities has been frequently drawn, both by visitors and by residents in the country, to the evils resulting from the indiscriminate bestowal of bakhshish to the inhabitants of the Nile villages, and other places visited by tourists during the winter season. The intention of the donors is no doubt kindly, but the practice-more especially in view of the yearly increase of visitors to Egypt cannot fail to be detrimental to the moral sense and the social well-being of the poorer classes of the community. At the present time, many of the poorer inhabitants of those towns on the Nile which are most visited by tourists, live almost entirely on what they can obtain by bakhshish during the winter months; the easy means thus offered of obtaining a small livelihood prevents their adopting any form of labour: and children are brought up to regard the tourist season as the period during which they may, by clamorous begging, enable their parents and themselves to lead a life of idleness for the remainder of the year. The unhealthy tendency of such a system is obvious.

"On the other hand, from the point of view of the Nile travellers themselves, the inconveniences of this universal mendicity are v equally obvious, and, as time goes on, cannot fail to increase, unless some means are adopted for checking the practice.

"It would be extremely difficult for the b Government to devise an effective remedy for N this state of things. The real remedy rests with the travellers themselves. If money were, in the future, only bestowed in return for some actual" service rendered, or in case of evident and" established distress, the present pernicious habit of begging would soon die out, to the advantage both of the people and of the visitors.

"It is with this conviction that the author- ities express their hope that travellers in Egypt will lend their aid to this important" reform by abstaining from the distribution of 1 money in response to mere demands for Bakhshish, bestowing it only when the circum-t . stances appear to them to warrant their generosity.

Tourists should especially abstain from throwing money from the decks of steamers on to the landing stages or on to the banks of the Nile for the purpose of witnessing the scramble for the coins-such exhibitions are mischievous as well as degrading.""

div.head: A PIPE INSTEAD OF DINNER
div.p: "I can't stop to eat now. I'll have a pipe instead."

div.head: MALTESE BENEVOLENT SOCIETY.
div.p: We recently published a telegram from

Archbishop Agius, of the Philippines, acknow- ledging the telegram addressed to him by the committee, and thanking the Maltese Bene- volent Society and colony in Alexandria for their congratulations on his elevation to the archiepiscopal chair.

A few days ago, Mr. E. T. Agius, the bishop's brother, and senior of the firm of Messrs. E. T. Agius, Limited, of London, wrote the following to Mr. Donovan, his agent in this city: "Would you kindly give my "warmest thanks to Mr. Mario Vella, the President of the Maltese community? Please tell him I wish to become a member of the Maltese Benevolent Society and if he will send me the "papers I will endeavour to start a branch here "with Marchese Alfredo Mattei, also a Maltese. "I will also be pleased to act as corresponding "member, and I think branches ought to be "started all over the world where Maltese are likely to be met with."

The committee, warmly appreciating the sen- timents expressed by Mr. Agius, on the motion of the president, have unanimously elected him honorary president of the society, directing its president to communicate direct with Mr. Agius acquainting him with the decision of the committee and thanking him in adequate
terms.

Mr. E. T. Agius is a member of one of the most influential families of Malta, which, with others, were first in establishing themselves in Egypt, at a time when Egypt was sorely in want of intellectual and energetic men to develop its resources. Having accomplished his mission in Egypt, he transferred his sphere of activity to London, where he founded the well-known firm of Messrs. E. T. Agius, Ltd., one of the most important firms in the coal trade, whose ramifications extend to all the principal ports in the globe.

Mr. Agius is highly respected in London and is known as a great philanthropist, especially towards his fellow-countrymen. The Maltese Benevolent Society and its president are therefore to be congratulated on having succeeded in interesting Mr. Agius in their good work.

div.head: RABIES AMONG DOGS
div.p: IMPORTANT NOTICE.

The Municipality considers it very necessary to draw the attention of the public to the fact that Rabies among Doge is at the present moment-great- ly on the increase. No less than four persons have died from rabies in the year 1904, and of these two in the last month.
As the Veterinary Service was not advised by these persons when they were bitten, the dogs were allowed to remain at large.
Ag-in, no less than 17 persons have been bitten to the knowledge of the Municipality in the last 2 months.

It is most essential that anyone bitten by a dog. cat, borse, or any other animal should at once advise the Veterinary Service of the Municipality (Telephone 1150) so that the animal can be caught and the necessary precautions taken.

It should be well understood that this should be done even though the animal may appear to be in perfect health-for it is only by examination that it can be ascertained if the animal is suffering from rabies.
The Municipality are determined to do their utter most to remove this scourge-bat they are almost powerless unless assisted by the public.
(Signed) W. P. CHATAWAY. Administrator.
Alexan Iris, November 10.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: Avis Important.
La Municipalité croit nécessaire d'a'tirer l'atten- ion du public sur ce que, ces derniers temps, les cas de rage sur les chiens out considérablement augmenté.

Dans le opurant de l'année, quatre personnes, mordues pir des chiens, sont mortes de rage, dont deux le mois dernier. Comme le Service Sanitaire n'avait pas été prévenu, les chiens a aient été laisrés en liberté.
De plus, il est à la connaissance de l'administra tion que: 17 personnes ont 6.6 mordues les deux derniers mois.

Il est indispensable que toute personne mordue par un chien, un chst, un cheval ou autre animal susceptible de rage, avise immédiatement le service vétérinaire de la Municipalité, téléphone N°1150, pour permettre au service d'attraper l'animal et de prendre les mesures requises.
Cet avis doit être donné même au cas où l'animal paraitrait en parfaite santé, oar ce n'est qu'après examen qu'on peut reconnaitre s'il est atteint de rage.
L'Administration est déterminés à employer tous les moyens pour enrayer le mal. mis ses efforts seraient impuissants sans l'assistance du public. Alexandrie, le 10 Novembre 19:4.
L'Administrateur, signed W. P. CHATAWAY,

Les personnes qui connaissent les

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
